meanings: open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning
not clear or decided

common: The lawyer's ambiguous statement left the jury confused.
The instructions were ambiguous, so I wasn't sure what to do.
fun: His answer was as ambiguous as a politician's promise.
The fortune cookie's message was delightfully ambiguous, promising both great wealth and sudden change.

translations.en: open to more than one interpretation; unclear or inexact

meanings: open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning
not clear or decided
意义不明确的
有多种解释的
to represent (something) as being larger, greater, better, or worse than it is

common: Fishermen often exaggerate the size of the fish they caught.
Don't exaggerate the difficulties; the task is manageable.
fun: He didn't just stretch the truth, he exaggerated it into a yoga pose.
My hunger wasn't just a rumble; I exaggerated it to a lion's roar.

translations.en: to represent something as being larger, better, or worse than it really is

meanings: to represent (something) as being larger, greater, better, or worse than it is
夸大
言过其实
a supposition or proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation
a proposition assumed as a premise in an argument

common: The scientist's hypothesis was that the plant would grow faster with more light.
We are testing the hypothesis that social media use affects sleep patterns.
fun: My hypothesis is that the missing cookies were taken by a crumb-loving ghost.
The detective's wild hypothesis turned out to be correct, much to everyone's astonishment.

translations.en: a proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence, a starting point for investigation

meanings: a supposition or proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation
a proposition assumed as a premise in an argument
假说
前提
certain to happen; unavoidable

common: After the scandal, his resignation seemed inevitable.
With their star player injured, defeat was inevitable.
fun: The inevitable result of teaching a parrot to swear is a very embarrassing dinner party.
As soon as I washed the car, the inevitable rain began to fall.

meanings: certain to happen; unavoidable
必然发生的
无法避免的
to place or deal with (close together or side by side), especially for comparison or contrast

common: The exhibition juxtaposes Picasso's early drawings with his later paintings.
The film juxtaposes scenes of wealth with scenes of poverty.
fun: The chef loved to juxtapose unexpected flavors, like chocolate and chili.
Juxtaposing his tiny kitten with a giant St. Bernard made for a hilarious photo.

translations.en: to place or deal with close together for contrasting effect

meanings: to place or deal with (close together or side by side), especially for comparison or contrast
将...并置
把...放在一起对比
a figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable, to suggest a resemblance.
a thing regarded as representative or symbolic of something else, especially something abstract.

common: The poet used the metaphor of a stormy sea to describe her inner turmoil.
'Time is a thief' is a common metaphor for how quickly life passes.
fun: His explanation was so confusing it felt less like a metaphor and more like a secret code.
My cat's relationship with the laser pointer is a perfect metaphor for the futility of desire.

meanings: a figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable, to suggest a resemblance.
a thing regarded as representative or symbolic of something else, especially something abstract.
一种修辞手法，用一事物暗示另一事物
比喻的说法
a seemingly absurd or self-contradictory statement or proposition that when investigated or explained may prove to be well founded or true.
a situation, person, or thing that combines contradictory features or qualities.

common: The statement 'less is more' is a classic paradox.
It is a paradox that standing is more tiring than walking.
fun: The paradox of my diet is that I think about food more now than I ever did before.
He embodied the paradox of being a fiercely private celebrity.

meanings: a seemingly absurd or self-contradictory statement or proposition that when investigated or explained may prove to be well founded or true.
a situation, person, or thing that combines contradictory features or qualities.
看似矛盾但可能正确的说法
自相矛盾的情况或人
able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
(of a substance or object) able to recoil or spring back into shape after bending, stretching, or being compressed.

common: Children are often remarkably resilient in the face of adversity.
This type of plastic is highly resilient and won't crack easily.
fun: My phone is surprisingly resilient, surviving multiple drops onto concrete.
She had the resilient optimism of a weed growing through a crack in the pavement.

meanings: able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
(of a substance or object) able to recoil or spring back into shape after bending, stretching, or being compressed.
能迅速从困难中恢复的
有弹性的，适应力强的
to examine or inspect closely and thoroughly.

common: The committee will scrutinize the budget proposal for any irregularities.
He scrutinized the document, looking for any hidden clauses.
fun: My dog scrutinized the new piece of furniture as if it were an alien artifact.
I had to scrutinize the menu for ten minutes before I realized I was holding it upside down.

meanings: to examine or inspect closely and thoroughly.
仔细或批判性地检查
审视
lasting only for a short time; impermanent.
(of a person) staying or working in a place for only a short time.
a person who is staying or working in a place for only a short time.

common: The feeling of sadness was only transient and soon passed.
The city has a large population of transient workers during the summer.
fun: My interest in learning the accordion was charmingly transient.
The cat treated us not as owners, but as transient staff in her royal palace.

meanings: lasting only for a short time; impermanent.
(of a person) staying or working in a place for only a short time.
a person who is staying or working in a place for only a short time.
持续很短时间的
转瞬即逝的
短暂停留的人
